awd_titl_txt: PIXEL2020: The 10th International Workshop on Semiconductor Pixel Detectors for Particles and Imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports the 10th International Workshop on Semiconductor Pixel Detectors for Particles and Imaging (PIXEL2020), to be held in Santa Fe, New Mexico on December 14-18, 2020.  This workshop will advance technologies that enable discoveries at the highest energies, of the rarest processes, in astrophysical and space applications; in nuclear, heavy ion, and cosmology contexts; in synchrotron light and lepton beams; and in a variety of health, communications, and defense applications requiring radiation hardened materials.

This workshop will review existing and proposed pixel detectors for particle physics and for x-ray imaging.  Issues to be discussed include new designs and architectures, radiation effects, simulation, alignment and calibration, mechanical stability and cooling, electronic readout and front-end ASICs, and triggering.  
 
This award supports the attendance of up to 25 participating graduate students and junior investigators. As all sessions will be plenary, this meeting will provide excellent exposure for these junior scientists. Proceedings will be made available for the use of the worldwide instrumentation community. This workshop will bring to the Southwest international experts on instrumentation. Developments will have potential applications to medicine, astrophysics, biology, and nuclear and particle physics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Stipends were provided to 16 graduate students and postdocs to facilitate their participation in the Tenth International Workshop on Pixels for Particles and Imaging.  For some it was their first conference experience.  All gained professional visibility, contacts and networking opportunities important for career advancement, and experience in professional communications.  These stipends were offered to all graduate students and postdocs who registered for the conference.  The availability of the stipends was announced via web site, posters, and verbal communications.  The conference was held in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA, and sponsored by the University of New Mexico.  Over 100 physicists from around the world attended.  The workshop spanned 5 days.  Delegates were exposed to the latest breakthroughs in pixel-based particle detection, including technologies relevant to medical imaging, infrared detectors, direction electron detection, x-ray and light source facilities, and astrophysical systems, as well as for high energy physics.  Elements reported about pixel detection included sensors, readout electronics, mechanical supports, cooling, powering, integration, fast timing, response to radiation damage, and the CMOS, SOI, and DEPFET technologies, All talks were plenary.  A dedicated poster session was held as well, and posters remained available for viewing throughout the meeting.  Proceedings were published, so that all presentations are permanently archived with open access.
